 If an all-powerful God exists as God is described by the Christian Bible, for example, it is possible that this God has a well-defined line between the concepts that we call 'right' and 'wrong.' (Or similarly, these concepts can be labeled morally 'good' or morally 'bad' or 'evil.')
 
 However, no one existing in the physical realm knows whether any specific definition of God is absolute... let alone whether or not a God or many gods or no gods exist.
 
 It takes faith to believe that the concepts of 'right' and 'wrong' are absolute. Faith is very subjective -- it is dependant upon personal experience. In other words, no matter what you believe, there is no way to know within the physical realm whether your beliefs coincide with any absolute morals as defined by a God -- if that God even defines absolute morals, and if that God even exists.
 
 So my short answer is this:

 My even shorter answer is this:
 The concepts of 'right' and 'wrong' are completely fabricated by humanity.
